title: quake jolts argyll from slumber
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowIt may be tiny on a global scale, but a magnitude . earthquake which hit Mid Argyll earlier this week caused quite a stir.Its effects were felt as far away as Ballycastle and Edinburgh, and it even attracted national news outlets to our corner of the world.A deep, sonorous boom accompanied the quake, which is reported by the British Geological Surveyto have been centred near Achnamara.It struck around .am from a depth of km, and people across Argyll were woken from by the noise as homes trembled for a second or two.Lochgilphead resident Sharyn Grfin, who was about to head for bed at the time, said: #I was watching TV when there was a loud boom followed by the whole block of flats I live in rumbling. It was quite unsettling. I could feel it through my feet and I live on the first floor.#Robbie MacTavish from Lochgilphead said: #I got woken up with what I thought was thunder, then there was a massive boom and the whole house shook. I#ve never felt anything like it. I thought a bomb had gone off.#It has to be said, though, that many Argyll folk slept right through it.Brian Baptie of the British Geological Survey explained: #There are about two earthquakes of this size or bigger somewhere in the UK every year, and tens of thousands globally.#Over the last  years we have recorded six earthquakes with a magnitude of four or above somewhere in Scotland.#

title: jim-telfers-contribution-world-rugby-recognised
story: BORDERS rugby legend Jim Telfer is to be inducted into World Rugbyrsquos Hall of Fame .The former Hawick High School and Gala Academy headmaster won  caps for Scotland,  as captain.And he made eight test appearances for the British and Irish Lions, on two tours, in  and .A tenacious back-row forward for Melrose, Telfer has the distinction of being the only Scotland international to have played New Zealand, South Africa and Australia without losing.Following his playing career, he became one of the most revered coaches in the game.He coached the Lions on their  tour to New Zealand, Scotland to the Five Nations Grand Slam in  and, as assistant to Sir Ian McGeechan, to a second Grand Slam in .After a break from coaching, Telfer was invited by McGeechan to become forwards coach on the triumphant Lions tour of South Africa in .Through his technical know-how and stirring motivational speeches, Telfer galvanised a Lions pack written off by the press and they laid the  for a - series victory.Telfer, with the assistance of John Rutherford and Hugh Campbell, was successful again in  as Scotland claimed the last-ever Five Nations title under their management.The six stars were selected by the Hall of Fame committee. This comprises of John Eales, David Hands, Henri Garcia, Pablo Mamone, Rob Cole, Anna Richards and Wayne Smith.Eales, the chair of the committee, said: ldquoThe  inductees for the World Rugby Hall of Fame are representative of all that is good in our game. Each of them have been outstanding players in either sevens or s and they have also been important contributors to rugby, in their own countries and globally, off the field.

title: gala-fairydean-rovers-announce-new-initiative-youngsters
story: Gala Fairydean Rovers Academy players will now be invited to all home first team matches with free entry.The Lowland League Club feel that it is important for the youngsters to see where the GFR pathway leads to.Neil Hastings has also voiced his support and looks forward to seeing all players and coaches down at Netherdale soon.He said: ldquoWhen I first arrived at the club it was clear to see there was  still is a lot of excellent work going on with the youth academy. As someone who has always had an interest in youth development and also someone who has worked at ious clubs with youth players, I understand all the dficulties and challenges along the way.ldquoFirst and foremost, when I arrived at the club I had to concentrate on the st team and this will obviously always be my number one focus. However, I now believe we are moving in the right direction, and I really want to try and create a real family environment at the club.ldquoNothing would make me happier on a Saturday to walk out at pm and see as many of the young GFR family shouting, cheering, and supporting the st team. We have the full pathway now for young players at the club from starting their football journey Up to under s football and then the lowland league side.ldquoI think its important for a young players development that they see where they are aiming to try and play. I have spoken with Davie about a few ideas to try and build a relationship between the First team and the young players as I understand its a two-way street and we cant just ask for them to come along a create an atmosphere. I would love for us to get to a point in a few yearrsquos time where we dont need to ask for ball boys, mascots or for them to attend but to hear that theyre heading to Netherdale for the game with their friends anyway.

title: scotland-v-south-africa-tv-channel-kick-off-time-scotland-rugby-match
story: Scotlandwill play South Africa in their third match of the rugby autumn series this weekend at Murrayfield.Last week the team played against Australiain front of a home crowd, winning -in a close and dramatic match.Now turning their attention to South Africa, the odds looktipped in the latters favour, with the team having won the last six head-to-heads.However, Scotland comes off the back of two triumphs and with a home crowd behind them once again, the team will look to extend their successful run.South Africa arrive in Edinburgh following their -win over Wales last week, so regardless of the final outcome of Saturdays match,it looks set to beexciting.As rugby enthusiasts once again fill up the Edinburgh stadium, heres how you can watch at home...Kick-off time for Scotland v South Africamatch this weekend The Scotland v South Africa match will take place at Murrayfield on Saturday November at pm.It is Scotlands third game in the autumn series, which will take place throughout November.What channel isScotland v South Africa and how to watch live Amazon Prime hasthe broadcast rights for the autumn international series in the UK.You will need a membership to tune in, butyou dont already have one you can sign up to a -day free trial.If you dont want to continue your trial after the -days however, you will need to remember to cancel your subscription.When is Scotlands next match in autumn series Here is Scotlands schedule for the autumn series:Scotland v South Africa: Saturday November  at pmScotland v Japan: Saturday November  at pmWhats the Scotland team line-up The Scotland team for Saturdays match is yet to be confirmed.Meanwhile, this was the line-up for last weeks match against Australia:Stuart HoggDarcy Graham, Chris Harris, Sam Johnson, Duhan van der Merwe Finn Russell, Ali Price Pierre Schoeman, George Turner, Zander Fagerson, Sam Skinner, Grant Gilchrist, Jamie Ritchie, Hamish Watson, Matt Fagerson..removeReplacements:Ewan Ashman, Jamie Bhatti, Oli Kebble, Jamie Hodgson, Josh Bayliss, George Horne, Adam Hastings, Kyle Steyn.

title: newtown-st-boswells-play-park-officially-opens
story: A NEW play park has officially opened in Newtown St Boswells.The pound, site is part of Scottish Borders Councils pound.million investment in play parks and outdoor community spaces programme.The accessible for all park is suitable for children aged from three-years-old to  and is the second destination play park to be opened this year ndash a play park at Peebles Victoria Park opened in May.Selkirkshire councillors, Gordon Edgar, Caroline Cochrane and Elaine Thornton-Nicol, said: ldquoThis new, custom-built play park in Newtown St.Boswells is an extremely exciting development for the local area.ldquoItrsquos absolutely crucial when creating a facility like this that it is designed to meet the needs of the people who will use it most and it was extremely pleasing to be able to include local primary school children throughout the design process and get their input and feedback throughout.The park includes a specially design safety surfacing mural which depicts the Newtown St Boswells area and has a central multi-play unit.Eildon Housing Association gave more than pound, and Buccleuch Estates gave more than pound, to the development of the park.As part of the councils ongoing play parks programme, facilities in Duns and Jedburgh are set to open in  in addition to ongoing plans for a skate pump track in Jedburgh and skate park in Peebles.SBC convener councillor David Parker said: ldquoThe Council has made major strides in the last few years in bringing our play park and outdoor community spaces up to date with outstanding modern facilities.ldquoThis new play facility will rank as one of the best in the Borders and will signicantly enhance the community facilities on offer for our young people.ldquoI have no doubt this will make a positive contribution to the local area and will offer countless hours of fun and enjoyment to young people in the Borders.

title: nicola-sturgeon-covid-update-today-watch
story: Nicola Sturgeon will give a Covid update today - her first in two weeks due to COP duties.Health secretary Humza Yousaf and deputy first minister John Swinney both filled into deliver Covid updates during the climate conference, but today it will be Sturgeon back at the podium.It comes just one day after UK prime minister Boris Johnson delivered a press briefing on Covid in the UK, during which he refused to rule out the prospect of further restrictions over Christmas.These words mirrored those of the Scottish government, which has also repeatedly refused to rule out bringing back measuresrequired.Monday was a busy day for Covid news: in the morning before Johnsons pmbriefing, it was confirmed people aged - in the UK would be offered a booster jab, with data showing thatthree doses of the vaccine cuts risk of infection by more than %.Young people aged - will also be offered a second dose, having been given only one jab the first time round.These changes are all likely to be covered in the First Ministers update today, so heres when and how you can watch...What time is Nicola Sturgeons Covid update today Nicola Sturgeon will give a Covid update to Parliament at around .pm today.This time is subject to change, depending on previous items including topical questions running to time.How can I watch Nicola Sturgeons Covid update today The First Ministers Covid update will be broadcast live on BBC Scotland from :pm.It will also be streamed on the Scottish governments social media s, as well as live tweeted on the SNPs Twitter.What will the First Minister say at Covid update today As always, the First Minister will provide an update of the Covid stats in Scotland, including infection rates and hospitalisations.She is also likely to give further details on the announcement that people aged - will be offered a booster jab, and youngpeople aged  and  will be offered a second dose..removeWith winter closing in, we couldhear more about the governments plans to reduce transmission in the cold weather.We could also learn more about the impact of COP on Scotlands Covid rates.

title: first-mndf-burns-supper-held-january-2022
story: MY Namersquo Doddie Foundation has announced a new long-term charitable partnership with events and wellbeing business hasta World, which will see them host Londons most exclusive Burns Night celebrations together over the coming years.The inaugural MNDF Burns Supper will be held at The Brewery, Moorgate on th January , and while it will honour the legendary Scottish poets le and work, it will also raise vital funds for Motor Neuron Diseaseresearch.Rob Fee, Director at hasta World, said: ldquohasta are absolutely delighted to support Doddie and the fantastic work the Foundation are doing to raise awareness of MND. Bringing the My Namersquo Doddie Burns Supper to the heart of London is going to be a great way to reach so many with messages about the Foundation, itrsquos incredible work and to raise vital funds to support the growth of the Foundation for years to come".Jill Douglas, CEO at the My Namersquo Doddie Foundation added: "Partnerships like the one with hasta help us deliver our long term strategy - supporting people living with motor neuron disease and investing in targeted research and wersquore extremely grateful and excited for this long-term partnership with the hasta team as we know this support can be le-changing to many"Guests will enjoy an unforgettable evening of entertainment with a four-course dinner accompanied by bagpipes, drams of Whisky and live music, as well as a line-up of well-known celebrities from the worlds of sport and television who will entertain with poems and songs.Availability is extremely limited, contact burns@hastaworld for further details.

title: coronavirus-borders-records-60-cases-24-hours
story: THE Borders has recorded  new cases of coronavirusin the last day, latest figures show.According to Scottish Government data published at pm today , the Borders has now seen ,cases of the virus since the start of the pandemic.There are  people in the hospital in the Borders with confirmed cases of the virus ndash three more than yesterday.Scotland has now recorded , cases of the virus since March last year, according to the latest data.

title: learn-becoming-teacher-scottish-borders
story: THE SCOTTISH Borders Council are looking to hear from graduates currently living in the Borders who would be interested in obtaining a qualication that would allow them to gain GTCS registration as a primary or secondary teacher.The opportunity is being provided through a partnership agreement with the University of Highlands and Islandswho offer a Professional Graduate Diploma in Educationprimary or secondary programme for graduates with a degree.Alongside opportunities to train to teach in the primary sector, the secondary courses offered are:biology with science, business education, chemistry with science, computing science, English, home economics, mathematics, physics with science and technological educationAn Honours degree at : or above is preferred as the programme sits at Honours and Masters levels. Applicants must also hold National  Mathematics and Higher English . At secondary level there are specic entry guidelines for inidual subjects.The programme is full time for one year with students required to carry out online, collaborative and inidual study, interspersed with school placements. School placements will be within the Scottish Borders and students will have access to local and UHI tutor support. Please note that all arrangements will be subject to relevant COVID- restrictions.Upon completion of the programme, students will apply for the GTCS Teacher Induction Scheme to be offered a yearrsquos probationary teacher position in a Scottish Borders school. They will then be entitled to apply for posts within the local authority.The closing date for applications for the August  academic year is  January .Anyone who is interested in finding out more is invited to take part in one of the following virtual drop-in sessions:Wednesday  November, -pm or Tuesday  November, -pmTo find out more and to get details on how to access the sessions, email: CPD@scotborders.gov.uk or phone  ..removeCouncillor Shona Haslam said: ldquoThis really is an exciting and innovative way for anyone with a relevant degree to join us. Wersquore a highly forward thinking, ambitious Education Service, deeply committed to delivering high quality learning opportunities for the benefit of all our children, young people and staff.ldquoOur world-class Inspire Learning programme is just one example of that commitment, harnessing the latest technology, curriculum innovation, new learning environments and high quality professional development to ensure that learning across our region is mobile, personal, collaborative and excellent.ldquoI would encourage anyone who wants to be part of our vision to get in touch and find out more about the programme. The online sessions are an ideal starting point as yoursquoll be able to speak to not only members of our schools team but also students who have already taken part in and benefitted from the programme.

title: nicola-sturgeon-covid-update-say-today-new-rules-considered
story: Nicola Sturgeon was back giving a Covid update today in Parliamentafter a two-week hiatus due to COP hosting duties.In her absence over the past two Tuesdays, health secretary Humza Yousaf and deputy first minister John Swinney stepped in, with the latter warning last week that changes to the current rules could be on their way.Indeed, today not only marked the First Ministersto the Covid briefings, but also the three-weekly review of the restrictions currently in place, when the government decides whether to adapt current measures.The past two days have seen a flurry of Covid related announcements Boris Johnson gave a press briefing yesterday in which he refused to rule out the reintroduction of restrictions in England, and the vaccine booster scheme was extended to include --year-olds.Nowin the aftermath of COP, which experts warned could lead to a spike in cases, the Scottish government is consideringimplementing some changes to the current Covid measures in Scotland.Heres everything you need to know.... Current regulations remain in place with no changesToday marked the three-week review of Covid rules, with the Scottish government deciding not to implement any changes at the moment.However, the First Minister did confirm they were considering making changes to the current rules on vaccine passports, with a decision due to come in the coming days.. Vaccine passports in hospitality settings being consideredLast week deputy first minister John Swinney said the government was considering extending the use of vaccine passports to wider hospitality settings.Today, the First Minister confirmed that these changes were still under consideration.If such measures are introduced, it would meanpeople wouldrequire vaccine passports to visit venues such as indoor theatres,cinemas and some licensed hospitality venues, as well as nightclubs and large scale events.Any changes would be introduced from December , according to the First Minister..remove. COP did not lead to a signicant rise in casesDespite experts warning before the climate conference that we could see Covid figures surge, this does not currently appear to be the case, according to the First Minister.She said that although we couldnt draw "finalconclsuions" as of yet, "there is no sign so far of any signicant spike in cases associated with COP".The First Minister also used the example of COP as a reason to use lateral flow tests, which she advised people took twice a week as well asremindingthe public that these tests can be ordered online for free.. --year-olds will be invited to book their booster jabs soonYesterday it was confirmed that people aged - in Scotland would be offered a Covid booster jab, after results found that a third dose signicantly improved protection.On Monday, the online portal opened for over-s in Scotland to book their booster jabs, with the First Minister confirming over-s would be invited for their boosters once the top priority groups were vaccinated.Booster jabs can only be given -weeks or  months after receiving the second dose of the Covid jab.. Covid cases are rising slightly in ScotlandDespite COP not yet seeming to have a huge impact on figures in Scotland, the First Minister did confirm that Covid cases were rising slightly, with the daily average up to around ,.In the last  hours, , new cases of Covid were reported, while  people were in hospital and in intensive care.A further  deaths were recorded.Speaking on these figures, the First Minister said: "The numbers reported in recent days here in Scotland - which Irsquoll come on to talk about - illustrate the need for continued precautions. So too does the challenging situation being experienced again across Europe."Drawing on infection rates in Germany and Austria among other European nations experiencing surging Covid numbers, Ms Sturgeon added: "All of this is a reminder that governments everywhere are grappling with the same issues and dilemmas we are.". Covid rates in older population decliningCovid case rates may be rising slightly, but they are decreasing amongst the older population.Infection rates in the + age group are declining, which the first minister suggested was likely linked to the Covid booster jab, with  million third doses administered.. Scotland most vaccinated area of UKThe First Minister added that Scotland was the most vaccinated nation in the UK, saying: "It is worth pointing out that on first, second, booster and third doses, Scotland is currently the most vaccinated part of the UK."That is down to the incredible hard work of everyone involved in organising and delivering the programme and I want to record my thanks to each and every one of them."

title: second-jobs-mps-borders-representatives-share-thoughts
story: THE Bordersrsquo Westminster representatives have had their say as the row over whether MPs should be allowed second jobs continues.Labour will vote tomorrowon banning MPs from taking paid directorships or consultancies in a bid Sir Keir Starmer says would help to end ldquododgy lobbying.It comes after then-North Shropshire MP Owen Paterson, of the Conservatives, was found by the Commons Standards Committee to have used his position to benefit two companies who paid him as a consultant.Mr Paterson said his integrity had been ldquorepeatedly and publicly questioned, and claimed he was ldquototally innocent of breaking lobbying rules.:Second destination play park of the year opens in Newtown St BoswellsOn the issue of second jobs, Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk MP John Lamont said: ldquoHaving been a Borders MSP and then MP for almost  years now, I know that my job takes up almost the entirety of my time.ldquoMy priority is helping constituents and representing them in Parliament.The Conservative representative added: ldquoSplitting my week between my home in Coldstream and Westminster leaves little time for anything .Earlier this month, Mr Lamont and fellow Borders representative David Mundell, also of the Conservatives, voted in favour of changing the way MPs are policed ndash pausing Mr Patersonrsquos suspension for breaking lobbying rules.:Coronavirus: Borders records more than  cases in -hour periodThis was met with outrage from opposition parties, forcing a government U-turn.When asked about MPs having second jobs, Mr Mundell ndash representative of Dumfriesshire, Clydesdale and Tweeddale ndash said: ldquoOver my  years as a Member of Parliament, I have always taken the view that this is a full-time job, and that is why I have never had a second job or had any other paid outside interest.MPs are currently allowed second jobs as long as they are not a minister.

title: get-booster-vaccination-borders
story: NHS Borders has issued guidance on Covid- booster and flu vaccinations in the region.Vaccination teams have offered Covid- booster and flu vaccinations to the majority of care home residents and staff in the Borders.People on the highest risk list who were severely immunosuppressed at the time of their last Covid- vaccination are being offered a third primary dose instead of a booster. All iniduals in this group have been offered an appointment.Vaccinations for those who are housebound are underway and staff will contact people prior to coming out to see them in their homes.Those aged  years and over and adults aged  years and over who are on the highest risk listhave now received their appointment details by postfor their Covid- and flu vaccination.If you are in these groups and have not received your letter please call the national Covid- Vaccination Helpline on   .Those aged - and also those aged  to  years with underlying health conditionswill receive their appointment lettersthis week. Clinics were scheduled to start from Sunday  November onwards.The next phase of the vaccination programme was due to commence from Monday  November when a self-booking portal was launched for appointments throughout December. The self-booking portal will allow all adults over , carers as well as people aged  to  years with specic risk factors that make them eligible under the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation rsquos clinical advice to come forward and arrange an appointment. People can check eligibility details at NHS Inform.Vaccinations will now be administered by NHS Borders in community clinics instead of by inidual GP practices. Some vaccinations may still be administered in a practice building by NHS Borders staff.Those who are housebound will continue to get their vaccination at home and care home residents will get their vaccination in their care home setting. Please do not contact your GP practice to book your appointment as they will not be able to book it for you..removeAnyone eligible who has tested positive for Covid- must wait  days after a positive test to get the Covid- booster.The booster programme is running alongside NHS Borders biggest ever flu vaccination programme. Wherever possible those eligible will be offered their Covid- and flu vaccines together.At least  weeks should have passed since receiving the second dose of the Covid- vaccine, before a booster is administered.A recent amendment to the Green Book, which is the vaccination and immunisation guide for health staff, supports extra flexibility for people to receive Boosters after a five monthwait from primary dose completion. This is only possible in the following circumstances: in a care home setting to enable all residents to be vaccinated in the same session or where an otherwise eligible inidual attends for another reason A further amendment to the Green Book allows for people who are about to receive immunosuppressive treatment to receive their Booster after a period of four months . This is to avoid giving the Booster when the immune system is less able to respond.Iniduals who are not eligible for a Covid- booster until later this year and onwardscan opt to get their free flu vaccination at one of the participating community pharmacies now.Details of participating pharmacies can be found here: http:www.nhsborders.scot.nhs.uk media  Pharmacies-Participating-in-.pdf

title: hawick-reports-ordered-man-admitted-5-offences
story: BACKGROUND reports have been ordered into a Borders man who admitted a total of five offences.Twenty-year-old Adam Redpath, of Hawick, pleaded guilty to two counts of assault, two charges of vandalism and threatening or abusive behaviour.Sentence was deferred at Jedburgh Sherf Court until December .You might also be interested in:Coronavirus: Number of vaccination record errors concerning, says Borders MSPJailed: Banned Borders driver crashed carwith two other occupants in itNHS Borders guidance on Covid- booster and flu vaccinationsin the region

title: amazon-visa-customers-cant-use-uk-issued-visa-credit-cards-2022
story: Amazon has told customers that they wont be able to use Visa credit cards issued in the UK from the beginning of next year to pay for items on the site.The change will come in from January , according to the company.Currently Amazon users can choose to pay viaVisa, Delta, Visa Electron, MasterCard, EuroCard, American Express, UK based Maestro and Solo card, with this including Visa credit cards.However, in an email to customers, the companyconfirmed it will stop accepting payments made using Visa credit cards issued in the UK "starting January  ".UK-issued Visa credit cards will no longer be accepted due to "the high fees Visa charges for processing credit card transactions".Customers will still be able to use debit cards, including Visa, and non-Visa credit cards.Meanwhile, Bloomberg has reported that Visa credit cards that have been issued outside UK will still be available for use.A spokesperson for Amazon said:"The cost of accepting card payments continues to be an obstacle for businesses striving to provide the best prices for customers."These costs should be going down over time with technological advancements, but instead they continue to stay high or even rise."As a result of Visarsquos continued high cost of payments, we regret that Amazon will no longer accept UK-issued Visa credit cards as of January  ."With the rapidly changing payments landscape around the world, we will continue innovating on behalf of customers to add and promote faster, cheaper, and more inclusive payment options to our stores across the globe."

title: openreach-borders-broadband-boost-part-95m-investment
story: BORDERERS are set for a ldquomajor broadband boost as part of a pound million Scottish investment by Openreach.The digital network provider has already announced plans to upgrade  towns across the region, including Galashiels, Hawick, Peebles and Selkirk.And now Chirnside, Lauder, Coldingham, Clovenfords and Stow will be upgraded following the latest announcement, with an ldquoultrafast, ultra-reliable network to be built to most premises in these areas.Robert Thorburn, partnership director for Openreach in Scotland, said: ldquoAs Scotlandrsquos biggest fibre builder, wersquore delighted to be unveiling another broadband boost for more people in the Scottish Borders.:Coronavirus: Number of vaccination record errors concerning, says Borders MSPldquoGood connectivity is vital ndash whether itrsquos to work from home, access education and care services, or for gaming and streaming entertainment ndash and thatrsquos why wersquore investing across the UK to upgrade our network to  million premises.He added: ldquoMany rural and hard to reach communities are already benefiting and we plan to reach many more in the coming months and years.On the news, Scottish finance secretary Kate Forbes said that ldquodigital connectivity is more vital than ever.ldquoWith Openreachrsquos latest commercial investment of pound million, this will ensure more than  of our communities across Scotland will be able to access even faster full-fibre broadband, she said.

title: st-andrews-day-2021-bank-holiday-get-day-off
story: As the Scottishpatron saint day, St Andrews celebrations are exclusive to Scotlandwith no other part of the UK marking November .Officially, St Andrews Day is a bank holiday in Scotland however it doesnt necessarily mean we get a day off work...Heres everything you need to know...Is St Andrews Day a bank holiday in Scotland St Andrews Day was officially declared a bank holiday by the Scottish government in .However, banks are not required to close on November they do not want to.If  November occurs on a weekend, the bank holiday is moved to the following Monday.Do we get a day off for St Andrews day Despite being a bank holiday, employers are not actually required by law to give employees a holiday on the St Andrews Day bank holiday.Meanwhile, schools do not take St AndrewsDayoff meaning pupils are still required to go to school.What happens on St Andrews Day On St Andrews Day, the saltire must be flown on all Scottish government buildings.Any celebrations tend to revolve around Scottish food and drink like haggis and whisky as well as traditionalmusic and dancing.When are the next bank holidays in Scotland After St Andrews Day, the next bank holidays in Scotland are as follows:Monday December  : Christmas Day TuesdayDecember  : Boxing Day Monday January  : New Years Day Tuesday January  : Tuesday January  Friday April  : Good FridayMonday May  : Early May bank holidayThursday June  : Spring bank holidayFriday June  : Platinum Jubilee bank holidayMonday August  : Summer bank holidayWednesday November  : St Andrews DayMondayDecember  : Boxing DayTuesday December  : Christmas Day

title: coronavirus-borders-records-80-cases-24-hour-period
story: THE Borders has recorded  new cases of coronavirusin the last day, latest figures show.According to Scottish Government data published at pm today , the Borders has now seen , cases of the virus since the start of the pandemic.There are  people in the hospital in the Borders with confirmed cases of the virus ndash two more than yesterday.Scotland has now recorded , cases of the virus since March last year, according to the latest data.

title: leonid-meteor-shower-2021-see-scotland-week
story: A shooting star display could be visible in the UK on multiple occasions this week as the Leonid meteor shower makes its annual appearance.The Leonid shower is one of the most prolic meteor showers of the year and is associated with large numbers of shooting stars.Its usually spotted in mid-November, however it is best seenin clear weather conditions.Heres everything you need to know about the Leonid meteor shower this week and whether you can see it in Scotland...When will the Leonid meteor shower occur in UK The best time to see the Leonid meteor shower in the UK this week is in the early hours of Thursday morning, between midnight and dawn.It is expected to be clearest just before dawn when the moon has set, with predictions suggesting we could see up to  meteors per hour.The meteor shower could be spotted throughout the month, however it will likely be strongest and therefore most visibleearly in the morning on November .Can I see the Leonid meteorshower in Scotland To spot the Leonid meteor shower, certain conditions are required, including a clear nightsky.Unfortunately, weather conditions in Scotland for early Thursday morning look set to be cloudy with rain, which does not provide ideal conditions for seeing shooting stars.Those in the south are in for a better chance atseeing the display, with more intermittent cloudand dry weather forecast.However, we cant rule out seeing the meteor shower in Scotland for goodeven though Thursday morning will mark the point with the most shooting stars, the Leonid shower could continue in the following days, just with fewer meteors.Its best therefore to keep your eyes peeled over the coming days to be in with a chance of spotting some shooting stars.Where am I most likely to see shooting stars Generally, the shooting stars are easier to see in rural places away from street lights and light pollution.Its also good to be in a wide open space to give maximum opportunity to see the stars light up the sky..remove

title: doug-allans-latest-show-its-wrap-coming-borders
story: AWARD-winning natural history photographer, documentary filmmaker, er, author and public speaker Doug Allan is coming to the Heart of Hawick on Monday  November.He is touring Scottish theatres this Autumn with his latest show ldquoItrsquos a wrap, sharing his extraordinary filming challenges and successes.Part retrospective, the show is also Dougrsquos perspective on climate change and its impacts on the worldrsquos wild places. What change of emphasis and direction should we now be incorporating in wildle films He said: ldquoThere are big days when animals behave spectacularly right in front of your lens. And other quieter times when a deeper understanding reveals itself, a new insight into the environment and whatrsquos alive there. Irsquoll be talking about these moments of truth and how theyrsquore the biggest privilege of a wildle cameraperson.ldquoIrsquove always balanced optimism with reality but the latest world climate report lays bare the need for radical, urgent action. There are solutions, and I want to talk about them. Theyrsquore all challenging, some are scary and depend on us making deep changes to how we live. The planetrsquos at a crossroads and wersquore at the wheel. The next few years are going to be exciting.Sir David Attenborough once commented ldquoWildle cameramen donrsquot come much more special than Doug and in his  years of filming hersquos been involved with more than  films, freelancing for the BBC, Discovery, National Geographic and others.He was principal cameraman on many prestigious award-winning programmes, making over  trips to the Antarctic and more than  across the Arctic, filming for series including Hostile Planet, Forces of Nature, Operation Iceberg, Frozen Planet, Ocean Giants, Human Planet, Le, Planet Earth, The Blue Planet and Le in the Freezer.Doug speaks with passion and authority about the challenges of plastics and climate change. His topside and underwater filming - from the ice covered polar seas to tropical coral reefs -combined with his scientic credentials as a marine biologist, have given Doug unparalleled first hand experience and a unique long term perspective on these issues which are now severely impacting our environment. He was one of the cameramen for, and appeared in, the award winning documentary A Plastic Ocean..removeDougrsquos photographic awards include eight Emmys, five BAFTAs and five Wildscreen Pandas and has twice won the underwater category in the Wildle Photographer of the Year. Doug has three Honorary Doctorates in recognition of his camerawork and an Honorary Fellow of the prestigious Royal Photographic Society and Honorary Fellow of the Royal Scottish Geographic Society. In  he was awarded the RSGS Mungo Park Medal for his contribution to geographical knowledge in hazardous environments.Tickets available now from www.liveborders.org.uk

title: bgh-stade-de-france-finlay-christie
story: Borderer Finlay Christie is in contention to start for the All Blacks in this weekends Test with France in Paris after recovering from a neck injury.Born at Borders General Hospital and raised in Peebles before the family emigrated to New Zealand when he was seven, the -year-old Auckland Blues scrum-half did his selection chances no harm with a superb performance against Italy two weeks ago after coming off the bench to replace Brad Weber.Despite giving away an offside scrum penalty with first involvement he then impressed to give Head Coach Ian Foster some thinking to do.In the th minute he made the most of a big All Blacks scrum that turned over possession just metres from the line and touched down for his first try for the team.He later provided a great assist for Sevu Reecersquos try.He was on the bench for last weekendrsquos defeat in Dublin andhe is now fully fit and available for selection.New Zealand forwards coach John Plumtree yesterday confirmed that fly-half Beauden Barrett is a "doubt" for the game after failing a head injury assessment in Dublin during last Saturdays loss at Ireland which potentially opens the door for Christie."He hasnt completed all his protocols yet. Hes in doubt I would say, especially with Thursday being our final preparation day Plumtree said."Brad Weber has played really well on this tour and Finlay Christie is up and coming. We have some really nice choices to make."The game at a sold-out Stade de France is a dress rehearsal for the opening match of the  Rugby World Cup.

title: dog-fouling-sbc-look-new-measures-tackle-issue
story: A GALASHIELS representative has held a "very constructive" meeting with the councils chief executive over the issue of dog fouling.At a meeting of the towns community council this month, Euan Jardine, of the Conservatives, said the dog poo problem across the Borders was getting "worse and worse".Last week, the Galashiels councillor had a meeting with Netta Meadows, Scottish Borders Councils chief executive, to discuss the issue.:Borderers set for lsquomajor broadband boostrsquo as poundm investment plans revealedldquoIt was a very constructive meeting with some background on approaches the council has attempted to deal with this issue over the last few years," said Mr Jardine. "There is a strong consensus that of course the council can and will look at new measures to tackle the issue."He added: "Unfortunately, there will always be irresponsible dog owners who do not pick up after their dog. I will continue to work at developing plans to help tackle this issue and happy for people to get in touch with any ideas they may have on this matter.No dog fouling fines were handed out in Galashiels by the CAT team between January and June, according to a document.

title: newcastleton-bench-anyone-feeling-low-stressed-anxious
story: TO MARK World Kindness Day a lsquoBreathing Spacersquo bench was placed in Newcastleton, overlooking the village on the popular lsquoTwo Bridgesrsquo walking route, as a reminder of how important it is to be kind to each other and to ourselves.The bench features a lsquoTake Some Breathing Spacersquo plaque to promote the Breathing Space helpline which is available at evenings and weekends for anyone feeling low, stressed or anxious.Head of Health Improvement, Fiona Doig, said: ldquoThe past  months have been extremely challenging for many of us. Coping with stress and change is a very personal thing which can be dficult, so itrsquos important to be kind to yourself and others.ldquoThere are things you can do to look after your own mental health like taking a few moments to sit on a bench and enjoy nature, walking outside, connecting with other people or even just accepting kindness that others offer. Building ways to be well into our daily lives helps us to improve our mental wellbeing.ldquoPlease remember that help is available should you need it through national confidential helplines like Breathing Space and Samaritans. In addition to these, locally we have the Mental Health  Wellbeing Point on NHS Borders website which has resources, advice and self-referral forms for our Wellbeing Service.Breathing Space National Coordinator, Tony McLaren, commented: ldquoWersquore delighted to be unveiling this bench in Newcastleton to mark World Kindness Day. Creating welcoming outdoor spaces to pause, reflect and connect is crucial for mental wellbeing. Our Breathing Space advisors are also available in the evenings and throughout the entire weekend on     for anyone needing more support should they be experiencing distress in their lives.Newcastleton  District Community Trustrsquos Enterprise, Learning and Community Outreach Manager, Claire Musson added: ldquoNewcastleton has experienced signicant trauma in the last two years. We have suffered two major floods which displaced people from their homes and causing great anxiety around the future. Like many rural communities, Covid has created an even greater sense of isolation for this remote village, and we have lost valued members of our community in tragic circumstances..removeldquoWe are therefore thrilled to be the recipient of a Breathing Space bench, as a marker of the new relationships which we are building with the wider network of mental health and wellbeing support. We hope this bench will support our mission to start an open conversation around mental health and provide accessible pathways to the help people need.

title: watch-live-rugby-borders-weekend
story: This weekendrsquos rugby kicks off tonightwith a Border derby between Kelso and Melrose at Poynder Park. This game is in National League One but the points will also count for the Borders League.Also tonight in National East League Division One Duns host Haddington whilst in National East League Two Hawick Linden have a home game against Livingston.Jed-Forest host Peebles in the Border League.On Saturday Gregor Townsendrsquos Scotland face Japan in the final game of the Autumn series at BT Murrayfield. Kick off for that game is pm.In the Premiership, Selkirk host Currie at Philiphaugh.In National League Division One Gala take on Biggar at Netherdale.In the Reserve East League Division One Selkirk A take on Currie A.In the Reserve East League Division Two Gala A host Peebles Reds.In the Semi-Junior Borders League Selkirk Youth are away to Alnwick Colts, Melrose Wasps travel to face Carlisle Colts, Duns Colts host Kelso harlequins in a Borders derby, Gala Wanderers host Jed Thistle and Peebles Colts are away to Morpeth.The Hawick Youth game against Tynedale Colts has been postponed.On Sunday Kelso Ladies have an away fixture against Ayr.As always times may change so make sure you confirm that the game is on before travelling.

title: dancers-return-peebles-stage-weekend-performances
story: DANCERS ed to the Eastgate Theatre last week after year due to the coronavirus pandemic.Members of the Fiona Henderson School of Dance took to the stage on November  and  in what was the first ever performance for some pupils.Senior pupils performed lsquoEclipsersquo which featured a range of dance styles ndash including ballet, tap, Highland, Scottish National, Irish, street, contemporary, jazz and modern.School principal Fiona Henderson said: ldquoWe were overjoyed to see our Seniors back on stage where they belong ndash doing what they love to do.ldquoThis yearrsquos show was the most technically ied and complex wersquove ever produced with  dances in total including solos, duets and group dances.ldquoTheir teachers and I were delighted with their performances, and I know from the ious messages and emails that their parents and other audience members thought likewise.And the youngest pupils, some as young as three-years-old, took part in their first ever show with a performance of lsquoForever Friendsrsquo.Ms Henderson added: ldquoOur Little Stars Show represents a real milestone for our youngest dancers ndash it is the first-time they have ever been on the theatre stage and with all that entails including the loud music, lighting and stage curtains and then being faced with a packed audience watching them.ldquoAnd they always rise to the occasion and never fail to disappoint.The Fiona Henderson School of Dance was established  years ago and now boasts eight branches across the Borders.The school was recently awarded Dance School of the Year .

title: council-reveals-unsuccessful-borders-bids-uk-government-fund
story: SCOTTISH Borders Councilhas revealed the unsuccessful bids to a UK Government fund.Last week, this newspaper reported that eight applications had secured a total of pound. millionfrom the Community Renewal Fund.But five bids failed to receive a cash boost, with one application still pending a decision.The unsuccessful projects were:pound, for lsquoConnecting Bordersrsquo by Live Borderspound, for lsquoPaddle, Pedal Connect: Communities Leading Tourismrsquo by Tweed Valley Tourism Business Improvementpound, for lsquoGH - Garages to Homesrsquo by Scottish Borders Housing Associationpound, for lsquoBurnfoot Bettermentrsquo by Burnfoot Community Futurespound, for lsquoEnabling Community-Led Housing: Scottish Bordersrsquo by South of Scotland Community HousingThe outcome of the pending bid will be ldquoannounced in due course, according to a UK Government spokesperson.After announcing the successful applications, council leader Shona Haslam, Conservative representative for Tweeddale East, said SBC would be ldquoworking closely with the failed applicants.She said: ldquoWhilst it is great news that eight projects have been successful in securing funding, we will be working closely with those unsuccessful applicants to identy alternative means of taking forward their projects.The money is part of a pound million UK Government funding pot ldquodesigned to support communities to pilot new ideas and approaches to better support people in need.The Borders was designated a ldquopriority place to receive funding up to a maximum of pound million, according to an SBC spokesperson.On the fund, a UK Government spokesperson said: ldquoThe UK Community Renewal Fund aims to support people and communities most in need across the UK, creating opportunities to trial new approaches and innovative ideas at the local level.ldquoThrough this fund, we will strengthen the relationship between UK Government and places across the UK..removeldquoThe UK Government will work directly with local partners, so that the people that know their places best are front and centre of the decisions that impact their areas and lives.ldquoThis fund will also provide capacity funding to help places prepare for the introduction of the UK Shared Prosperity Fund.

title: northern-ireland-unlikely-face-another-lockdown---chief-medical-officer
story: Northern Irelandrsquos chief medical officerSir Michael McBride has said he does not think the region is facing the prospect of another coronavirus lockdown.However, Sir Michael warned that Northern Ireland was facing a very serious situation and some further restrictions on certain settings may be requiredefforts to suppress the current Covid- wave fail.ldquoI donrsquot think that wersquoll go back to the situation that we had before, back in March last year, when we had that lockdown, he told BBC Radio Ulster.He said the vaccination programme meant a lockdown was less Michael said evidence indicated that was potentially ldquoone of the single most effective interventions.He said people did not need to cancel scheduled Christmas parties at this stage but advised them to take precautions to minimise risk, such as taking a lateral flow test prior to attending.Health Minister Robin Swann has unveiled the latest plans to accelerate the roll-out of COVID vaccine boosters and further increase first dose take-up.##https:t.co RSmohRplfpic vmRYxwKdmdash Department of HealthNovember , A further six deaths of patients who had previously tested positive for Covid- and another , cases of the virus were notied in Northern Ireland on Thursday.On the same day there were  Covid-positive patients in hospital, with  in intensive care.The CMO stressed the virus is title: austria-imposes-national-lockdown-covid-cases-continue-soar
story: Austrian Chancellor Alexander Schallenberg said that the country will go into a national lockdown to contain a fourth wave of coronavirus cases.Mr Schallenberg said the lockdown will start on Monday and initially last for  days.Most stores will close, and cultural events will be cancelled.He initially said said all students would have to go back into home schooling.Wolfgang Mueckstein, the countryrsquos health minister, later said that kindergartens and schools would remain open for those who needed to go there but all parents were asked to keep their children at homepossible.Starting on February , the country will also make vaccinations mandatory, public broadcaster ORF reported.ldquoWe do not want a fth wave, Mr Schallenberg said, according to ORF.ldquoNot do we want a sixth or seventh wave." data-title"Virus Outbreak Austria" data--holder"AP" data--notice"AP Press Association Images" data-credit"Michael Gruber" data-usage-terms"UK only" mandatory vaccinations in February.The chancellor said the details would be finalised in the coming weeks but those who continued to refuse to get vaccinated would have to expect to get fined.ldquoFor a long time, the consensus in this country was that we didnrsquot want mandatory vaccination, Mr Schallenberg said.ldquoFor a long time, perhaps too long..push,i[r].l*new
