Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownHealthCoronavirusBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium Majority of people in favour of mandatory Covid passportsExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseA new app which allows users to show proof of Covid- vaccination status within Northern Ireland was launched by the Department of Health earlier this month to facilitate voluntary checks in hospitality and entertainment venues. Credit:: Kirsty O#Connor PA WirePA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueA new app which allows users to show proof of Covid- vaccination status within Northern Ireland was launched by the Department of Health earlier this month to facilitate voluntary checks in hospitality and entertainment venues. Credit:: Kirsty O#Connor PA WireMark BainTwitterEmailNovember   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailThe majority of people in Northern Ireland would welcome the introduction of mandatory Covid passports, a new poll has indicated.Almost two thirdsof those questioned by Lucid Talk said they would have no issuethe passports were introduced for the hospitality sector to allow them entry to pubs, restaurants and nightclubs.A new app which allows users to show proof of Covid- vaccination status within Northern Ireland was launched by the Department of Health earlier this month to facilitate voluntary checks in hospitality and entertainment venues. Currently, people here are not required to prove their vaccination status to enter indoor hospitality or entertainment venues.Stormont recently published a contingency plan which referred to the “potential” deployment of Covid- status certication in “higher risk settings”.Vaccine passports are in force for designated hospitality venues in Scotland and Wales, but England scrapped similar plans.Support here is particularly strong amongst the older age group, with % of over- respondents saying they believe passports should be mandatory. That falls to just over halffor those aged -.The hospitality industry is largely against any such scheme, believing the sector should not be singled out for special treatment, having already been hit hardest by Covid restrictions.Femalesare more in favour of passports than males , according to the survey.There’s a dramatic split in support for Covid passports based on political voting preferences, with only % of the DUP voters questioned believing passports should be brought in as a mandatory requirement.Over half of the DUP voters polled were opposed to any passport scheme , but support was strong from Alliance Partyand Sinn Fein supporters .The polling also suggested strong support for compulsory Covid vaccinations for healthcare workers.Over two thirdsagreed health staff vaccination should be compulsory, with only a quarteragainst. An overwhelming majority of over ssaid the vaccinations should be compulsory, though that figure drops to % of those aged -.DUP voters were split on the issue with % in favour of making vaccinations compulsory and % against, but Allianceand Sinn Fein voterswere strongly in favour.A public consultation on compulsory Covid- and flu vaccination for new healthcare workers was announced last week. But Health Minister Robin Swann said any requirement for existing staff could be “counterproductive” and could further destabilise a workforce that is already severely depleted.Related title: actor laurence fox accused over tweet criticising alliance leader naomi long
story: Actor Laurence Fox. Credit: Isabel InfantesHealth Minister Robin Swann. Credit: Jonathan Porter   Press Eye FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueActor Laurence Fox. Credit: Isabel InfantesLisa SmythTwitterNovember   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailActor and political activist Laurence Fox is remaining tight-lipped over a controversial tweet in which he appeared to poke fun at the appearance of the Alliance Party leader.The outspoken opponent of lockdowns and face coverings is facing accusations of body-shaming Naomi Long for a social media comment he posted in response to the Executive’s decision to introduce Covid passports.Sharing a post by Vote Leave supporter Jeffrey Peel, which included a photograph of the Justice Minister, Mr Fox said: “She’s going to regret voting that way when the vaccine passport becomes a health passport.”He subsequently tweeted: “Stormont hasn’t been able to agree on anything for years. I do hope someone is following the money.”Read MoreAllison Morris:OpinionLatest online abuse directed at Naomi Long driven by misogynySinister Dungannon graffiti targeting Robin Swann condemned by local partiesMs Long and Health Minister Robin Swann have both faced a barrage of abuse since the controversial decision on Wednesday afternoon to approve vaccine passports in Northern Ireland.In addition to comments criticising Mr Swann on social media, the Health Minister has also been singled out in sinister graffiti. His name was daubed on a wall in Dungannon, along with a target mark.It appeared hours after a -year-old man was remanded in custody on charges which include making threats to kill Mr Swann as well as harassment and improper use of electronic communications.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up The abuse directed at Ms Long, in particular the posts by Mr Fox and Mr Peel, have prompted an outpouring of support from across the political spectrum. Lewis actor Mr Fox, the ex-husband of actress Billie Piper, has not responded to requests to comment on his controversial tweet.However, Northern Ireland Secretary Brandon Lewis was among political leaders who expressed solidarity with Ms Long.“The vile misogynistic abuse that has been directed towards her since yesterday’s vote is disgusting and has no place in this echo chamber or outside of it,” he tweeted.SDLP leader Colum Eastwood and UUP leader Doug Beattie also blasted the online abuse.Sinn Fein MP Chris Hazzard accused those behind the abuse of being “cowardly ... to launch the type of attack on a female public representative that Naomi Long has suffered on Twitter. Utterly pathetic.”Northern Ireland’s mental health champion Siobhan O’Neill, who wrote to the Executive to urge them introduce vaccine passports, also offered her support to Ms Long.“I stand in support of Naomi Long and in condemnation of vile, misogynist, personal attacks on women in public le,” she said.”Irish language activist Linda Ervine also pledged solidarity to Ms Long, describing her as “a woman who never lacks courage”.Related topicsNaomi LongRobin SwannUlster Unionist PartyThe Executive OfficeTwitterBrandon LewisSDLPDoug BeattieChris HazzardSinn FéinMore On Naomi Long title: belfast declared uks third most beautiful city with surprise building named prettiest so say the maths
story: The most beautul out of the buildings measured by the ratio was Belfast’s Central Library, scoring .% on the beauty score.titanic buildingThe Art Deco style Bank of Ireland building on Belfast#s Royal Avenue was built in the s.Belfast City Hall was listed scoring .%.The Waterfront Hall scored .%. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueThe most beautul out of the buildings measured by the ratio was Belfast’s Central Library, scoring .% on the beauty score.Amy CochraneTwitterEmailNovember   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailA mathematical formula has declared Belfast the third most beautul city in the UK.The “golden ratio” uses a set of proportions that many artists and scientists believe is the “epitome of natural aesthetic perfection”.Read MoreHey good lookin’: How Belfast got to be third most beautul city in UKIt was used by the Online Mortgage Advisor to measure the appearance of over , buildings in the UK to find out which cities have the most beautul buildings.The higher the score, the closer a city’s buildings are on average to match the golden ratio.The study, which analysed  streets, found Belfast was ranked third most beautul, coming in just behind Chester and London.Liverpool came in fourth place and Durham placed fth.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Each city was assigned a beauty score, with Belfast clocking .%.The most beautul out of the buildings measured by the ratio was Belfast’s Central Library, scoring .%.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseThe Art Deco style Bank of Ireland building on Belfast#s Royal Avenue was built in the s. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueThe Art Deco style Bank of Ireland building on Belfast#s Royal Avenue was built in the s.The library was one of the first major public library buildings in Ireland and first opened in .A competition for the design of the building was won by architect William Henry Lynn in  and it was built by H  J Martin builders.The library was designed to reflect the ambitions of the growing city of Belfast, and its architecture is considered to be a fine example of a public building at the height of the Victorian age, built from Dumfries red sandstone on a black granite base.Other high-scoring buildings include the Bank of Ireland building on Royal Avenueand the Titanic Belfast which scored .%.Belfast City Hall was also listed scoring .% and the Waterfront Hall also scored .%.Most ReadDonna Traynor taking ‘age bias case’ against BBC, corporation insider claimsBelfast declared UK’s third most beautul city with surprise building title: bertie ahern told to apologise for loyalist ghetto remark
story: Bertie Ahern, former Taoiseach, giving evidence to the Exiting the European Union Committee in the House of Commons  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueBertie Ahern, former Taoiseach, giving evidence to the Exiting the European Union Committee in the House of Commons By James Ward, PANovember   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailLoyalists who are opposed to the Northern Ireland Protocol “haven’t got a clue” about how it works, former Irish premier Bertie Ahern has said.Speaking at an event hosted by the Brexit Institute at Dublin City Universityon Thursday, Mr Ahern said they view the arrangements as being solely about identity.Unionist politicians hit out at the comments on Thursday evening.The former Taoiseach said the contentious post-Brexit arrangements are not properly understood by the community, and viewed as a backdoor to a united Ireland.He said: “I spend a lot of my le still in the North. The reality is in East Belfast and in the ghettos and in the areas where you’re likely to get trouble, is that people haven’t got a clue about the protocol, not a clue.“They see it as identity.“They see it as a road to the Dublin Government taking over again and this is a pathway to that. That’s the hard reality.”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up The protocol was designed to prevent a hard border on the island of Ireland, by introducing controls in the Irish Sea on goods travelling between Britain and Northern Ireland.The EU and the UK remain deadlocked in negotiations over its implementation, with the new barriers to east west trade creating tensions in some loyalist and unionist communities.Mr Ahern, a former Fianna Fail leader and one of the architects of the Good Friday Agreement, said the idea that Protocol is about trade “just passes them by”.He added: “In fact they’re not interested. It’s seen as a trick by the south to move the border from across the island, and to put it down the Irish Sea, as a trap for government.“That’s how they see it. Even those who you might consider to be a bit more intelligent and articulate. That is the dficulty.”Mr Ahern said negotiations over the protocol are made more dficult by this view.He said: “We’re trying to do two things. We’re trying to solve the dficulties of medicine and meats and everything  in the protocol.“But there’s another issue in the protocol, and that’s what is in the head and the ideological one, and that’s a far more dficult one to deal with.“ Jeffrey Donaldson well understands how we might get over the detail, and the reason he keeps on about the other issue is because he’s trying to – which I don’t blame him for – he’s trying to serve the loyalist community as well.”"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming fa .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_ee-ba--aa-baab_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming fa .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_ee-ba--aa-baab_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming fa .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_ee-ba--aa-baab_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming fa .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_ee-ba--aa-baab_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Gavin Robinson PA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueGavin Robinson  DUP MP for East Belfast Gavin Robinson called on Mr Ahern to apologise for his comments.“To associate East Belfast with a ghetto and suggest loyalists are not able to understand the protocol is demeaning and degrading,” he said.“People in my constituency who can’t get their Amazon parcels from another part of the United Kingdom well understand the impact of the protocol.“Rather than belittling those who oppose the protocol, Bertie Ahern should seek to understand why not a single elected unionist in Northern Ireland supports the protocol.“As a man who was central to the Belfast Agreement being negotiated, Bertie should be honest in recognising that the protocol does alter Northern Ireland’s status within the United Kingdom single market without any consent from people living here.”Senior DUP MLA Diane Dodds was also critical.In a post on Twitter, she said: “Coming from the Dublin elite the snide comments in this piece about loyalist communities are despicable.”"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming c .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_ee-ba--aa-baab_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming c .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_ee-ba--aa-baab_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming c .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_ee-ba--aa-baab_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming c .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_ee-ba--aa-baab_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Minister for Foreign Affairs and Defence Simon Coveney PA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueMinister for Foreign Affairs and Defence Simon Coveney  Speaking earlier, Irish Foreign Minister Simon Coveney said the EU had offered a comprehensive package to the UK, aimed at easing the implication of the Protocol.He said: “This package represented a signicant compromise for the EU.“The lack of any evident reciprocal willingness to compromise from our UK partners to date has been deeply disappointing.“The protocol was agreed by Lord Frost and Prime Minister Johnson, approved by this British government and ratied by the current UK Parliament.Coming from the Dublin elite the snide comments in this piece about loyalist communities are despicable. https:t.co yABzYGNg— Diane Dodds MLANovember , “They have a duty to deliver on their commitments.“It is very important we do not lose sight of the goal here, ensuring an outcome that is best for the people of Northern Ireland.”Most ReadDonna Traynor taking ‘age bias case’ against BBC, corporation insider claimsBelfast declared UK’s third most beautul city SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremiumexclusive Donna Traynor taking ‘age bias case’ against BBC, corporation insider claimsExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseDonna Traynor FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueDonna TraynorClaire McNeillyTwitterEmailNovember   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailDonna Traynor is believed to be taking action against BBC NI for age discrimination.The popular TV news presenter dramatically quit her high-profile job on Monday with immediate effect.Although no reason was given for the -year-old’s sudden exit, the Belfastunderstands that it came after she was told her duties would be changing.Read MoreDonna Traynor BBC departure: The contenders to replace Newsline anchorIt may have resulted in the vastly experienced Lisburn-born presenter no longer being the first-choice presenter for the flagship Newsline programme, while she would also have been required to work on Radio Ulster shows.According to a well-placed source, Ms Traynor deemed BBC NI’s future plans for her unacceptable.“Donna was already unhappy at being occasionally sent out on reporting duties while others anchored the programme,” the source told this newspaper.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “What’s happened has certainly got nothing to do with her ability or her popularity.“She’s a huge favourite with the viewers, but maybe that’s no longer the case with some people inside Broadcasting House.“The thing about BBC NI is, new people come in and have new favourites. “Iniably, this can mean changes for existing staff, even though they’ve done nothing wrong.”Ms Traynor’s shock resignation after nearly  years follows on from other popular and established figures, such as Jackie Fullerton and Sean Coyle, being moved to “other duties” in recent years.Read MoreDonna Traynor BBC departure: The contenders to replace Newsline anchorNews of the long-standing presenter’s dramatic exit was revealed on social media on Monday, when she wrote: “It is with deep sadness that, after almost  years, I am leaving the job that I love and resigning from BBC Northern Ireland with immediate effect.”She added: “Because this is the subject of ongoing tribunal and other legal proceedings, I am not able to respond to any questions or comments about my reason for leaving the organisation.”In a statement issued to the Belfastyesterday, a BBC spokesperson said: “We do not comment on inidual staff matters.”Just over a decade ago, Miriam O’Reilly, who was  at the time, won her case for age discrimination against the BBC after she was dropped from the Countryfile rural affairs show.She took the broadcaster to an employment tribunal, which upheld her claims of ageism and victimisation.Ms O’Reilly claimed she was hounded out of the BBC after being unfairly blamed for newspaper stories criticising the corporation for dropping middle-aged women presenters.Read MoreBBC will miss Donna Traynor, says ex-anchor Seamus McKeeMs Traynor’s announcement was met with a mixture of shock and disbelief both inside and outside Ormeau Avenue.Facebook user Caroline Muldoon described the Newline anchor as “a pleasure to listen to”.She added: “I grew up listening to her calmness as she passed on dferent types of news sad and happy.”George Cook said: “Good luck and take care. You have always been a very good person. Good luck for the future.”And Sally Henderson said: “Sorry to hear she’s leaving. Very good news reporter. All the best for the future.”Former BBC NI anchorman Seamus McKee, who retired nearly two years ago, said that colleagues and viewers alike would feel the effect of Donna’s sudden exit.“I wasn’t expecting it,” he told the Belfast .“Donna has become such a presence and has been around for such a long time.“Her departure is not something I anticipated. “Her screen presence will be missed and I hope it won’t be for too long.”Read MoreBBC presenter Donna Traynor quits broadcasterMost ReadDonna Traynor taking ‘age bias case’ against BBC, corporation insider claimsBelfast declared UK’s third Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownNorthern IrelandNews HeadlinesBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium Hey good lookin’: How Belfast got to be third most beautul city in UKExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseProud buildings: Judith Owens, CEO of Titanic Belfast. Credit: Peter Morrison FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueProud buildings: Judith Owens, CEO of Titanic Belfast. Credit: Peter MorrisonAmy CochraneTwitterEmailNovember   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailIt has been argued that “beauty cannot be measured through mathematics” and ultimately the idea of beauty, within the world of architecture, “is in the eye of the beholder” according to a leading conservation architect based in Belfast.This comes after the city has been ranked as the third most beautul in the UK according to new research conducted using the “Golden Ratio”, after Chester and London.This mathematical formula is a set of proportions that many artists and scientists believe is the “epitome of natural aesthetic perfection”.The Online Mortgage Advisor measured the beauty of over , buildings and  streets in the UK to find out which cities have the most beautul buildings.Liverpool came in fourth place after Belfast and Durhamwas placed fth.Each city was assigned a beauty score, which was each city#s average percentage match to the golden ratio, with Belfast scoring .% with the most beautul building listed as Belfast’s Central Library, scoring .% on the beauty score.Other high-scoring buildings include the Bank of Ireland building on Royal Avenueand the Titanic Belfast which scored .%.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Belfast City Hall was also listed scoring .% and the Waterfront Hall also scored .%.Graeme Moore is a conservation architect at Consarc Design Group, a company which previously worked on two of the five buildings listed as the most beautul in Belfast.“Our company has carried out surveys at the Bank of Ireland building and also a major refurbishment of Belfast City Hall about  years ago,” he explained.“These are both fine examples of Belfast’s ied architecture from very dferent eras, and this research is very interesting that it brings together buildings from  years ago right up to the present day, which just goes to show there isn’t one style more beautul than the other.”Mr Moore pointed out that both the Belfast City Hall and Central Library are examples of Victorian architecture, the Bank of Ireland is reflective of the Art Deco movement in the s when it was built and the Titanic building and Waterfront are both examples of modern-day architecture, with the Waterfront built in the s and Titanic in the st century.He said that the Golden Ratio is not something “the average passer-by would normally notice”.“It’s something that wouldn’t be visually obvious, but it manests itself in creating a very elegant composition, adopted actually from measurements found in nature,” he explained.“I think beauty in architecture, however, can come from a whole iety of sources.“Belfast has a great array of styles reflective of dferent times in our history many buildings were lost unfortunately in WW or during the Troubles but some of the most historic buildings have survived, for example Belfast City Hall and the Central Library.”Graeme has worked in the conservation industry for the past  years and said that it is important to retain this vital built heritage for generations to come.“As a conservation architect we try to find sustainable uses for historic buildings, of course there are challenges, but there is something intangible about an existing building and I think that is what tourists to Belfast or any other city seek out,” he said.“Belfast came of age in the Victorian era so that would have radiated out from the City Hall including fine public buildings and also industrial buildings to do with linen production, adding character to our history, which is very evident in the buildings standing today.”When asked what makes a modern building “beautul”, the architect explained that the materials are important to consider.“It’s important for new buildings to pick up on the materials and character of the old buildings, not necessarily to create a pastiche of what’s been there before, but instead show that they are of their own time and that they respond to building heights and proportions of their historic predecessors,” he said.“Nowadays there is such a iety of buildings in the city, reflective of each inidual time, environment and landscape, so really beauty is in the eye of the beholder and it cannot be judged on any one scale.“I don’t believe that there is any one definition for beauty, either, it doesn’t always come from mathematics, I think there are many factors to consider and each of these buildings listed all have their own unique traits and examples of beauty.”Most ReadDonna Traynor taking ‘age bias case’ against BBC, corporation insider claimsBelfast declared UK’s third most beautul title: ni amazon users receiving delivery emails saying they are republic of ireland customers
story: Online giant has invested more than £m here since  according to the firmExpandExpandPreviousNext" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseThe automated email Amazon customers in Northern Ireland appear to be receiving that wrongly state they are Republic of Ireland customers. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueNovember   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailAmazon customers in Northern Ireland appear to be receiving automated order confirmations emails that mistakenly state they are based in the Republic.The email gaff, which has been seen by the Belfast , states: “Hello, Ahead of the busy shopping period we wanted to provide you with some advice and guidance to make sure you get the most out of Amazon as a customer in the Republic of Ireland.The message goes to outline the online retailer’s Prime membership benefits.Amazon has been contacted for comment.In September figures released by online retail giant Amazon revealed the company has invested more than £million in Northern Ireland since .According to Amazon UK’s Economic Impact Hub, the company has generated around £m toward Northern Ireland’s gross domestic product over the last  years.The company employs around  full and part-time staff in Northern Ireland, with around , local small and medium businesses selling their products on the huge online market.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up At the time it was also announced Amazon is to open a new site in Portadown, Co Armagh which will create at least  permanent jobs and over  “driver opportunities”.It will be the company’s second delivery station in Northern Ireland.Meanwhile, Amazon is also creating  jobs at its first warehouse in the Republic, and is setting up the fulfilment centre in Dublin to meet customer demand.Read MoreAmazon figures reveal company’s £m NI investmentMost ReadDonna Traynor taking ‘age bias case’ against BBC, corporation insider title: no interest in irish sign on dungannons irish street
story: No replies to Mid Ulster District Council surveyExpandExpandExpandPreviousNext" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseIrish Street in DungannonIrish Street in DungannonUUP councillor Alan Lewis FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueIrish Street in DungannonBy Adam Morton, Local Democracy ReporterNovember   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailResidents on Dungannon’s Irish Street have shown zero interest in dual language signage, it has emerged.A survey issued to  people living on the street on August  garnered no responses by the September  deadline.It is currently Mid Ulster District Council policy thatmore than % of completed replies do not indicate a preference, a sign will not be erected.At a recent council meeting, the DUP’s Clement Cuthbertson criticised the running of such surveys after no responses materialised for the latest. He branded the exercise a “waste of money, time and effort from council officers”.“I want to highlight again the fact another street survey has come back with no responses,” Mr Cuthbertson said. “This is another waste of money, time and effort from council officers. Also, Irish Street is in the town centre. It is not recognised as a residential area and should be treated dferently.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “It is good to see the people on Irish Street don’t want Irish.”Sinn Fein councillor John McNamee said: “We should look at doing town centres in a dferent way then.“That is a conversation for another day, but I take your point and it is a point well made.”Separately, an Ulster Unionist councillor in Newry, Mourne and Down District Council has said a vandalised road sign at the historically signicant Dolly’s Brae site shows what is wrong with his council’s bilingual policy.Alan Lewis added: “The road sign at Dolly’s Brae has remained damaged for well over a year. Somebody has scraped, peeled or otherwise removed the English name, leaving only the Irish.”The councillor said he “purposely let this sit to see how long it would remain”, and that there had not been “a single objection from one other elected representative”.“Had this been the Irish removed, we could have been ensured a chorus of objections from a selection of Sinn Fein MLAs and councillors,” he added.“The fact is that the sign has been damaged in the reverse [and] nobody seems to care.“The Dolly’s Brae site is signicant to the Orange Order because it was the spot of a major confrontation between the Ribbonmen and ing lodges who had been in Tollymore for their annual celebrations and religious service on July , .“I suspect those damaging this sign recognised the historic signicance of their actions.“It again demonstrates how isive these signs are. They can be used by either side of the community to make a political statement, focus anger or ide communities.“Although not a supporter of the bilingual signs, I have asked that this one be repaired and due consideration be given to erecting a historic plaque to commemorate the battle that took place at this location.”Most ReadDonna Traynor taking ‘age bias case’ against BBC, corporation insider Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownNorthern IrelandNews HeadlinesBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremiumOur health service was crumbling long before it was struck by CovidLisa SmythExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseAn increasing number of people waiting for a hospital appointment are becoming emergency cases, requiring admission to hospital. Credit: Peter Byrne FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueAn increasing number of people waiting for a hospital appointment are becoming emergency cases, requiring admission to hospital. Credit: Peter ByrneNovember   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailEven prior to the pandemic, it wasn’t unusual for trusts to struggle to find space for patients in their hospitals.As far back as , the Royal College of Nursingwas warning about the dangers of squeezing hospital beds into areas without oxygen points and call bells, while overstretched staff complained they didn’t have enough time to take toilet breaks or administer medication to their patients.The situation deteriorated to the point where thousands of healthcare staff took industrial action at the end of , but there was barely any time between the end of the strike and the arrival of Covid- for NHS workers to catch their breath.So, it’s little wonder that almost two years of a global pandemic have had such a profound effect on the health service.As of Wednesday, there were  Covid occupied beds across the hospital system here, which is  beds not available for the patients who need treatment for non-Covid conditions, some of whom are acute medical emergencies, while others have been suffering without treatment for years.And while they languish on ever-stretching hospital waiting lists, their conditions worsen and they turn more frequently to their GP to manage their symptoms.However, there aren’t enough family doctors in Northern Ireland to cope with demand, resulting in more people going to AE for help.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up At the same time, an increasing number of people waiting for a hospital appointment are becoming emergency cases, requiring admission to hospital.Meanwhile, staff are exhausted, an unknown number are living with the effects of long Covid, others are trying to process the trauma of working through the pandemic, while the workforce is depleted further due to the requirements of isolation.Add to that the shortage of resources in the community, which makes it so dficult to discharge patients from hospital, and it has created the perfect storm in which we now find ourselves.It is true that the vaccines have put us in a better position than this time last year — but only to a certain degree.Despite the rush when they first became available, health officials have struggled to reach their target uptake.Public confidence in the vaccinations has been damaged by the messages coming from some politicians, as well as the disappointment that they aren’t the silver bullet many people mistakenly believed they would be.The fact that they reduce the likelihood of catching the virus, experiencing serious illness and even decrease the chance of dying from Covid- doesn’t seem enough to convince the sceptics that they are an efficient tool in getting us through the pandemic.Sadly, some have taken an all or nothing approach — either the vaccine works % of the time or it isn’t worth getting, even more so now they have realised the vaccines don’t protect for le.Then there are others who can’t see the bigger picture and the reality that by being vaccinated, they are reducing the risk to those most vulnerable from the virus.Waning immunity is also likely to be a factor in Northern Ireland’s depressing case rate. That’s why the booster programme is so important — but even that doesn’t appear to be rolling out as quickly as hoped. All of this is set against a backdrop of an Executive that has pressed ahead with lting restrictions despite the most ardent warnings from health professionals over the state of the health service.Over the summer, officials were once again caught off guard by the might of Covid-, as case numbers spiked a number of weeks sooner than expected.At the time, they blamed the less than impressive vaccine uptake for the surge in positive cases.As a result of the premature peak, operations were cancelled as staff were erted from their normal roles to help care for the influx of seriously ill patients.Even as the health service faltered and pupils ed to class, the Executive approved further relaxations — at the same time there was a contact tracing disaster in our schools.By the time politicians gave the green light to the reopening of nightclubs, health workers were well and truly exasperated by the path we were on.It was abundantly clear that it wasn’t the best move to allow hundreds of people, many unvaccinated, to cram together in loud and unventilated venues, without social distancing or face coverings, while also adding alcohol into the mix.Even more incredibly, the relaxation was timed to coincide with the Hallowe’en holiday. The warnings from staff on the frontline became more frantic. Unusually senior officials even joined the chorus, with Seamus O’Reilly from the Northern Trust explaining that emergency departments may have to shut in response to the mounting pressure.Then as last weekend approached, rumours began to swirl that the AEs at Antrim and Craigavon were close to collapse, emergency plans were put into place to bolster staff numbers and free up beds. Antrim Area Hospital struggled through, but the measures weren’t enough to stabilise the situation at Craigavon.An ambulance ert was implemented twice in the space of -hours, putting further pressure on the hospitals that stepped in to assist.Dr Tom Black from the British Medical Association gave an ominous warning.“This is only the start of it,” he said, as the crisis appeared to finally shake the Executive into action. Eventhere was an acceptable Covid- death rate, the impact of coronavirus goes much further than those who lose their lives as a result of this wicked respiratory virus.The elderly pensioner waiting eight hours on the floor before an ambulance arrives, the families caring for frail loved ones due to a lack of care in the community, the parents sending themselves into debt to fund their child’s much-needed operation, the nurses, porters and paramedics who consistently work hours past their finish time to give the best possible care to their patients despite the system falling down around them.They’re all casualties of this mess we’re in.It wasn’t dficult to predict, as we failed to meet keep coronavirus under control, vaccination rates stuttered, the temperatures started to drop and winter viruses began to circulate, that even a small number of Covid- cases would be enough to tip the NHS over the edge.Related topicsAntrim Area HospitalCraigavon Area HospitalThe Executive title: revealed catholic staff more likely to work at junior level in ni civil service
story: The report also focuses on the gender pay gap. Photo: izusek FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueThe report also focuses on the gender pay gap. Photo: izusekGarrett HarganTwitterEmailNovember   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailCatholics working for the Northern Ireland Civil Serviceearn .% less on average than Protestants, according to new statistics.There is also a gender pay gap in the service, with a higher proportion of women than men in lower-paid roles. A report by the Northern Ireland Statistics and Research Agencyfound Catholic staff were paid an average of .% less than Protestant colleagues.The report provided an overview of basic pay statistics for the NICS over the past year.It showed there was a higher proportion of Catholic staffin lower-grade positions.More Protestant NICS employees are at senior levels, meaning their median pay is weighted at a higher grade.The report said: “An overall NICS community background median pay gap can arise, even when inidual grades do not have a median pay gap, due to the overall staff profile of the NICS and dfering proportions of staff in lower-paid grades among Catholics and Protestants.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “For example, while the majority of both Protestant and Catholic staff remain in the EOand below grade, there is a higher proportion of Catholic staff in that group compared with the proportion of Protestant staff.“As a result of this, the median pay for Protestant staff is within the EOpay scale, whereas the median pay for Catholic staff is within the EO pay scale.“However, there are dferences at inidual grade levels, particularly in lower-paid grades. For example, there are higher proportions of Catholic staff at AOand EO levels, whereas the majority of staffat SCSare Protestant.”There continues to be a gender pay gap, with the median pay for women .% lower than the median pay for men.Nisra cited the staffing profile of the service as the primary reason for this, with a higher proportion of women working in lower pay grades.As of March this year, the majority of womenin the NICS were at EO grade or below, while the majority of menwere at EO grade or above.As such, the median pay of female staff lies within the EO scale, and the median pay of male staff in the EO scale.In the industrial one wage band, female median pay is .% higher than it is for menAmong other staff, such as those not on NICS pay scales, female median pay is .% lower than male median pay.For gender and community background, dferences of this kind can arise from a range of factors, including dfering proportions of staff in lower pay grades, the report said.Nisra also noted that any increases in pay could be explained by normal progression up a scale — for those people who are not at the top of their grade — and pay scale changes.The average basic pay of NICS staff is now £,, up by more than % on last year. This reflects a change in the median of all pay scales in the service and does not equate to a pay increase.The reason for the overall increase in pay across the NICS is that there has been a sht in the overall grade profile, which has moved the median from a point between the EO and EO pay scales upwards.Basic pay of £, would put someone in the bottom % of staff, whereas salary of £, would put someone in the top %.Around % of staff received an increase in pay between last year and this year.The extent of the increase ied across the grades. For example, % of staff in the industrial two band received an increase between .% and .%.At SCS level, % received pay increases of between .% and .%. These increases can be explained by the fact that the majority of SCS staff are not at the top of their pay scale.The median pay of staff at AO grade in the NICS is higher than in England, Scotland and Wales.Most ReadDonna Traynor taking ‘age bias case’ against BBC, corporation insider claimsBelfast declared UK’s third most beautul city with surprise building named prettiest – so say the Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownNorthern IrelandNews HeadlinesBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium Stark impact of Covid on arts revealedSurvey shows % of ticket sales slashed and % drop in employmentExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseAdam Turkington said that ‘people don’t think of art as work’. Credit: Stephen Hamilton FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueAdam Turkington said that ‘people don’t think of art as work’. Credit: Stephen HamiltonAllan PrestonTwitterEmailNovember   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailThe stark impact of the pandemic on Northern Ireland’s arts sector has been laid bare in a new report.Ticket sales for   were almost wiped out as they plummeted by % and employment levels in the arts sector drop by a quarter.The Arts Council of Northern Ireland’s Annual Funding Survey said there had been “substantial shts” in employment levels and income generation.As organisations shted their business models to online output there were also just  in-person physical events, a staggering drop from , the previous year.A total of  organisations took part in the survey, all of which received funding from the Arts Council’s Funding Programme , the largest financial award for key arts organisations every year.The survey considered factors like income and expenditure, numbers of performances, exhibitions and festivals as well as estimated audience numbers.For the first time, the impact of Covid- on organisations was also included.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Many of the Arts Council’s core funded organisations had to develop new business models to reflect changes to their operating environment. This often meant the sht from in-person to digital forms of output and changes to staffing levels.Looking at the rest of the findings, the survey found that £.m in Arts Council grants from Exchequer and Lottery resources was paid out to  organisations in  , the same figure as the previous year.This contrasted with a drop in income for   of £.mand earned income of £mcompared to the previous year.The loss was offset, to an extent, by increases in income from public sources including the Arts Council’s Emergency Funding Programme and contributed sources, both of which increased by %.There were , people employed by Arts Council funded organisations, representing a % drop year on year.In addition there was a further % drop in contract freelance staff and a % drop in permanent staff.While there were just  in-person activities, the combined audiences for online and digital activity rose to m.Adam Turkington is a freelance creative producer based in east Belfast.He said the impact of Covid- had been devastating for a sector that has already been in a state of financial crisis for a decade.“I feel that the problem that we have in general is that people don’t consider art to be work,” he said.“Another part of the problem is that, to an extent, the people tasked with looking after the arts aren’t fully aware of how many people work in the sector.“There’s a massive number of people who are freelance creatives who are getting on with lots of work without any support.“I’ve been lucky to be really busy over the last year. I’ve had to cancel most of the events we run, but I’ve being doing consultancy work and things like street art commissioning.“I realise that I’m not the norm and it is a really tough time. I’ll be honest though, many of the members of our community were really struggling for cash before the pandemic.”He continued: “Everyone’s inidual stories are dferent, but the Arts Council are largely talking about organisations that were already on the edge because a long term under funding.“So it doesn’t take much to put them in danger.“I run a street art walking tour, and I often say that in Northern Ireland we seem to think that people are artists because they’re too stupid to be doctors or lawyers, but not because they’re good at art.“Actually we should recognise that our artists are just as important members of society. They make le less boring.”Karly Greene, the Art Council’s Director of Strategic Development and Partnerships, said that while many organisations ersied during the pandemic, the online model was no replacement for the income generated by live events.“While we don’t yet know the long term impact these changes will have on the sector, this survey highlights a need for ongoing financial support and will be an important tool in helping us to strategically plan for the future.”Most ReadDonna Traynor taking ‘age bias case’ against BBC, corporation insider claimsBelfast declared UK’s third most title: tyrone uup association slam dictatorial approach after party selection of ian marshall
story: Ian Marshall with UUP leader Doug Beattie. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueIan Marshall with UUP leader Doug Beattie.Christopher LeebodyTwitterEmailNovember   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailThe decision to select a former Irish Seanad member as the Ulster Unionist Party’s West Tyrone constituency Assembly election candidate has been criticised by the local party association.Derry City and Strabane councillor Derek Hussey hit out at the UUP for “seeking to import” Ian Marshall into the constituency and said former councillor Andy McKane should have been chosen instead.A former MLA for the party, Mr Hussey branded the move a “dictatorial approach” from the UUP, saying he urged the party to reverse the decision.Read MoreIan Marshall selected as UUP Assembly candidate for West TyroneFormer Irish senator Ian Marshall joins ‘inclusive and erse’ UUPMr Hussey told the Belfaston Friday morning that the UUP have not yet been in touch with him regarding a statement put out by the association.Ian Marshall was confirmed to be the UUP’s candidate for next year’s Assembly poll in the constituency last month.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Mr Marshall from Co Armagh is a former President of the Ulster Farmers’ Union. He said he was persuaded to join the UUP earlier this year by party leader Doug Beattie.He was also the first unionist to be elected to the Republic’s upper chamber in  as an independent, but lost his seat in elections held last year.In a post on social media endorsed by the West Tyrone Constituency Association of the UUP, Mr Hussey said it was regretful the “unanimous wish” of the association – which had been ongoing over a period – was overruled by the party.He said Mr McKane had previously accepted the constituency association’s call and there was a “firm belief” that with him standing they could regain an Ulster Unionist seat in the West Tyrone constituency.“Regrettably, our party had other ideas, and determined to over-rule the unanimous wish of the West Tyrone Ulster Unionist Constituency Association by seeking to import Ian Marshall, from outside the constituency, to stand for the party in West Tyrone,” the post added.They said a meeting with Mr Marshall “resulted in those present declaring unanimously” that they would not support his candidacy.Mr Hussey said he could not support the “dictatorial approach that has been taken towards my long-time friends and colleagues of the West Tyrone Ulster Unionist Constituency Association”.He called for a “reversal of the current decision” and claimed “otherwise, we face the potential of snatching defeat from the jaws of victory”.Earlier this month, veteran UUP councillor Bert Wilson also criticised the decision to select the former Ulster Farmers’ Union president in the seat.Mr Marshall joined the UUP in the summer following the election of Doug Beattie as leader.At the time he hailed the “revitalised, positive and progressive unionism” within the party and said “the UUP is becoming much more inclusive and erse than perhaps it was a few years ago”.As part of the social media post post, prospective candidate Mr McKane said to have his selection overturned was “disappointing to say the least” and denied it was “a case of sour grapes”.“If the West Tyrone Ulster Unionist Association had chosen a dferent candidate from West Tyrone, I would have given that candidate my full support,” he said.“This is not about my ego, it is about West Tyrone Ulster Unionism and giving us the best chance of winning a seat back.“I believeyou must abandon your principles to gain favour then you are in bother. I am a Unionist with traditional values and make no apologies for being Unionist and British.”The Ulster Unionist Party has been approached for comment.Related topicsUlster Unionist PartyDoug BeattieMore On Ulster Unionist Party PremiumAlliance councillor Peter McReynolds who lives with multiple sclerosis to run for Stormont PremiumViewpointOpinionPoliticians do not deserve this abuseActor Laurence Fox accused over tweet criticising Alliance leader Naomi LongTributes paid to passionate NI football fan who died just before Italy game PremiumSarah CreightonOpinionWhy UUP needs ‘scundered’ unionists toto the foldMost ReadDonna Traynor taking ‘age bias case’ against BBC, corporation insider claimsBelfast declared UK’s third most beautul city with surprise building named prettiest – so say the mathsActor Laurence Fox accused over tweet criticising Alliance leader Naomi LongPictured: Inside south Armagh underground drugs factory raided by policeRevealed: Catholic staff more likely to work at junior level in NI Civil ServiceTop VideosPlayVideo: Inside Elk teen disco linked with  Covid cases and  having to self-isolatePlayContinental Circus Berlin wows the crowds at Boucher playing fields in BelfastPlayWatch: Derry Girls stars spotted filming latest series at Barry’s Latest Northern IrelandTele man elected to top post Covid-linked deaths in latest week analysed by statistics agencyGlentoran have what it takes to end -year winless run at Crusaders but it won’t be easy, says Mick McDermottRodney Brown: I had nothing to prove after Crusaders departure… I couldn’t be loving Coleraine stay any moreNews headlines: Power NI price hike... FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueRecent figures show of the  officers recruited in , three quarterswere Protestant and just %were Catholic.Allison MorrisTwitterEmailNovember   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailJust % of Sinn Fein voters questioned for a new survey said they would consider joining the PSNI or support a family member who wanted to join, with % saying they would not be okay with a career in policing.The Lucid Poll results come on the th anniversary of the handover from the RUC to the PSNI.Read MoreAllison Morris:OpinionTwo decades on and our police is still failing to win some hearts and mindsThe opinion poll also suggests that more SDLP voters support the current police service than DUP voters. The poll asked voters of each of the five main parties, “The Police Service of Northern Ireland is  years old this year. In this context would you personally consider a career in the PSNI and or support, or at least ‘be okay ’ with a family member considering a career in the PSNI”.Recent figures show of the  officers recruited in , three quarters  were Protestant and just %were Catholic.Earlier this month, the PSNI launched a new recruitment drive. One of its priorities is to increase Catholic officer numbers.The PSNI is hoping to hire  student officers in its latest recruitment campaign.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Alliance Party voters ed one of the highest rates of support for the PSNI, with % saying they would consider or support a family member considering a career in policing.Just % said they would not, with % undecided.Ulster Unionist Party voters showed the greatest level of support for the force, % saying they would personally think about joining or support a family member considering a career in the PSNI. However, % answered no to the question while % were undecided or didn’t have any opinion.DUP voters had greater numbers of people saying they would not support a career in policing. Of the party’s voters polled by Lucid Talk, % said they would not join or support a family member who wanted to join the PSNI.Just % of the party’s voters polled said they would consider a career in policing or a support a relative who wanted to join the PSNI.While no reason is given, the poll figures may have been impacted by recent allegations of two-tier policing by loyalists. Just % of the party’s supporters said they didn’t know or had no opinion on the matter.In April of this year loyalists rioted across Northern Ireland, with disturbances in Antrim and the Shankill Road area of Belfast. The decision not to prosecute any member of Sinn Fein in relation to the Bobby Storey funeral was cited as sparking the violence. The then DUP leader Arlene Foster called for the Chief Constable to resign as a result of unionist anger at police handling of the funeral.Across the political spectrum, some % of those asked the question indicated support for the PSNI by replying ‘yes’ with % answering ‘no’ and % either not sure or not having any opinion on the subject.Of the two main nationalist parties, SDLP voters indicated most support for the PSNI, with % answering ‘yes’ to the policing question. Those who said they would not support a career in policing amounted to around a thirdof the party’s voters polled, with a further % undecided.Sinn Fein politicians attended a PSNI recruitment event for the first time in . Deputy First Minister Michelle O’Neill and Policing Board member Gerry Kelly attended the event in what was seen as an open show of support for the force.In a recent interview with the Belfast , North Belfast MLA Mr Kelly said: “People have come to me, and there has been a number, looking for assistance to join the PSNI and I have assisted them.”However, he added that the build-up to republicans endorsing policing reforms was a “dficult” one. That appears to be reflected in the Lucid Talk results, with just % of SF voters polled saying that they would consider a career in policing or support a relative who wanted to join.Republicanism’s dficult relationship with the police, despite the Patten reforms, was demonstrated by nearly halfsaying they would not consider a career in policing or support a relative in joining the PSNI. There were % of Sinn Fein voters who said they either had no opinion or remain undecided.Related topicsPolice Service of Northern IrelandSinn FéinSDLPAlliance PartyUlster Unionist PartyArlene title: austria imposes national lockdown as covid cases continue to soar
story: People walk over a nearly deserted Christmas market in Vienna, Austria  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":truePeople walk over a nearly deserted Christmas market in Vienna, Austria By Kirsten Grieshaber, Associated PressNovember   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailAustrian Chancellor Alexander Schallenberg said that the country will go into a national lockdown to contain a fourth wave of coronavirus cases.Mr Schallenberg said the lockdown will start on Monday and initially last for  days.Most stores will close, and cultural events will be cancelled.He initially said said all students would have to go back into home schooling.Wolfgang Mueckstein, the country’s health minister, later said that kindergartens and schools would remain open for those who needed to go there but all parents were asked to keep their children at homepossible.Starting on February , the country will also make vaccinations mandatory, public broadcaster ORF reported.“We do not want a fth wave,” Mr Schallenberg said, according to ORF.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email introduced a national lockdown only for the unvaccinated that started on Monday, but as virus cases continued to skyrocket the government said it had no choice but to extend it to everyone.“This is very painful,” Mr Schallenberg said.The national lockdown will initially last for  days, then the effects will be assessed andvirus cases have not gone down sufficiently, it can be extended to a maximum of  days.Austria’s intensive care doctors welcomed the government’s decision.“The record infection figures that we have now experienced day after day will only be reflected in normal and intensive care units with a time lag.“It really is high time for a full stop,” Walter Hasibeder, the president of the Society for Anaesthesiology, Resuscitation and Intensive Care Medicine told Austrian news agency APA.“Given the current infection developments, we believe there are no alternatives to even greater contact restriction than recently, so any measures that help curb the momentum are welcome,” he added."data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news a .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_ebfd-fcf-f--de_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news a .ece AUTOCROP w visit a Christmas market in Vienna, Austria For the past seven days, the country has reported more than , new infection cases daily.Hospitals have been overwhelmed with many new Covid- patients, and deaths have been rising again, too.So far, , people have died of the virus in Austria.Austria, a country of . million, has one of the lowest vaccination rates in Western Europe, only .% of the population are fully vaccinated.Despite all the persuasion and campaigns, too few people have decided to get vaccinated, Mr Schallenberg said, leaving the country no other choice but to introduce mandatory vaccinations in February.The chancellor said the details would be finalised in the coming weeks but those who continued to refuse to get vaccinated would have to expect to get fined.“For a long time, the consensus in this country was that we didn’t want mandatory vaccination,” Mr Schallenberg said.“For a long time, perhaps too long.”Most ReadDonna Traynor taking ‘age bias case’ against Please allow ads as they help fund our trusted local news content.Kindly add us to your ad blocker whitelist.If you want further access to Irelands best local journalism, consider subscribing to our ePaper and or free daily Newsletter .Support our mission and join our community now.ePaperFree NewsletterMaybe LaterBuy an AdFree pass-- updateOgImageMetaTag newContentcontent.replaceconsole.logupdateOgImageMetaTag log.ajax isDarkModeEnabled .matchesYou are in:  DerryNow  Local News  County Derry Post --Dementia Social Club removing the stigma in rural areasMembers of Learmount Community Group accept a cheque for pound, from the McGrellis family for dementia services.The money was raised through a Golf Day held in memory of the late Dan McGrellis.Reporter: Orla Mullan Nov Email: editor@derrypost  addthis, In September , Caroline Lynch, the manager of Learmount Community Development Group, noticed that a few of their regular members had stopped coming to classes in the centre. googletag.cmd.push “A few of these people had been coming to classes even before I had started working here and I found it strange that they had just stopped coming all of a sudden,” she said. “One day I was in the shop and I met one of the members daughters and I said to her is your mammy not coming back   She told me she wasnt as she was in the early stages of dementia. This development within the Park-based group prompted Caroline to take action and so she got in touch with the Alzheimers Society straight away. Within weeks, the group had organised a dementia awareness workshop which saw almost  people turn up. Caroline said: “When we saw the turnout at these events we thought to ourselves theres something happening here, we have high numbers of people in the community looking for information on Alzheimer’s. “We were overwhelmed with the interest and numbers attending and this led to two further workshops being organised with one specically for businesses –  businesses attended. “The large attendance at the workshops subsequently led to the formation of a support group and a volunteer led signposting centre facilitated by Marie Gormley.” Having noticed the demand within the rural community for more support, Caroline helped set up a partnership between the Learmount group, Alzheimer’s Society and Claudy Health Centre to register to become a Dementia Friendly Community . The group also managed to secure funding through the Rural Development Programme, Housing Executive and Derry City and Strabane District Council. The funding was used to make dementia-friendly adjustments to the community groups building. This included signage, colour coding, training facilities and utensils that those with dementia could use. After seeing an advert in a paper for the Old Library Trusts Memory Cafe, Caroline set off for Derry to try and find out how she could set up a similar one in Park. This meeting started a conversation with the Old Library Trust who expressed an interest in including the Learmount group in their DEEDSproject. Shortly after the Old Library Trust secured funding through the National Lottery Community Fund for the project, Learmounts Dementia Social Club was born. Held every Monday morning, the social club have members from Feeny, Claudy, Park, Dungiven and Donemana attend. “We see ourselves as a Dementia Hub for the community and these mornings work so well for us – they are just the loveliest mornings and everyone benefits from them,” continued Caroline. “The carers come along as well and they get so much out of it too because they are meeting other carers who are dealing with the same concerns as them. “We have such great volunteers here in Learmount who have so much enthusiasm and dedication turning up weekly to help the group.” In , Learmount Community Development Group were nominated by the Alzheimers Society for their Dementia Friendly Awards, which they ended up winning. The north Derry groups services are also listed in the Alzheimers Societys literature which is distributed as far away as Scotland. “The social mornings happened so naturally and it just goes to show youthere is an identied need, opportunities will arise from it,” said Caroline. Although Covid- halted the social mornings run by the centre, they have since reconvened and members are delighted to be back. Just a few weeks back, Mayor of Derry City and Strabane District Council Graham Warke paid a visit to the Dementia Social Club to congratulate them on being awarded runner up in the Well Being Category of the IPB Pride of Place Awards. The group was nominated for the award by the council and were delighted to receive recognition for the work of their dementia volunteers, families, the Learmount Group and their DEEDS partners at the Old Library Trust. “Having this service is great because in rural areas it helps to remove the stigma and families are more willing to come forward and receive the support thats there on their doorstep,” continued Caroline. “We have guest speakers who come along to the social mornings and it’s just great to have that support around the table. “We would like to thank DEEDS, Claudy Health Centre and the Alzheimers Society for bringing their knowledge and support. They have been so supportive of the work that we are trying to do.” Although they are at full numbers for the social mornings at present, Caroline hopes going forward they will be able to get more families on-board. “Dementia sufferers get huge benefits from the social mornings, members look forward to coming here because it is a safe environment and they feel included in the community.” The McGrellis family recently visited the Dementia Social Club to present Patrick Conway, chairperson of the Learmount Group, with a cheque for pound, the proceeds from their Dan McGrellis, Memorial Charity Golf Day held on August . In total the McGrellis family raised pound, which was ided between Learmount Dementia Group and Marie Curie. Patrick Conway thanked the McGrellis family for the overwhelming amount raised at the charity event. Patrick continued that the generous donation would be used specically to retain dementia services in the local area and would have a huge impact on the support we can offer families. “Over the past six months, Learmount dementia services have received numerous donations from families living in the area – Shaun Mulhern and Ciaran Hutton, Annie-Teresa OKane and family and the McGrellis family - which we are so grateful for and it means that we wont lose our servicesfunding is stopped.” Patrick encouraged anyone who has a family member who has entered the early stages of dementia and would like support to get in touch by contacting the Learmount Group on . Please allow ads as they help fund our trusted local news content.Kindly add us to your ad blocker whitelist.If you want further access to Irelands best local journalism, consider subscribing to our ePaper and or free daily Newsletter .Support our mission and join our community now.ePaperFree NewsletterMaybe LaterBuy an AdFree pass-- updateOgImageMetaTag newContentcontent.replaceconsole.logupdateOgImageMetaTag log.ajax isDarkModeEnabled .matchesYou are in:  DerryNow  Local News  County Derry Post --Self belief and hard work earns Co Derry girl a World Champion titleEimhear OHara pictured with her trophy.Reporter: Orla Mullan Nov Email: editor@derrypost  addthis, They say good things come to those who wait. googletag.cmd.push For Foreglen teenager Eimhear OHara that was certainly the case when she was crowned U An Chomhdhail World Irish Dancing Champion at the start of November. For Eimhear, it was a moment she had been waiting on since  when she got her first taste of dancing at the prestigious competition which attracts Irish dancers from all over the world. “The first year Eimhear danced at the Worlds she came sixth. In  she came fth, in  she came third and in  she came second,” said Eimhears mum Bernie. With the Covid- pandemic hitting in early , Eimhears dreams of becoming a World Champion were put on hold once more. “She was so close the last year she performed at the Worlds and she just had it in her head that she was for doing this year – she was determined,” Bernie continued. Mum Bernie made the trip to Killarney with Eimhear, who has been dancing with the McNicholl School of Irish Dancing for approximately  years. She watched on proudly as her daughter took to the stage on November  to show her best moves to the judging . It was a tense wait at the adjudicators made their decision and when Eimhears number was called out Bernie said they both couldnt believe it. “We are just so delighted, there are no words for how we are feeling,” said Bernie “We are all just over the moon. Eimhear puts in a lot of work. She goes to classes three times a week and her daddy Anthony got her her own wee studio out the back so she can practice at home. Shed be out there for an hour or more every night.” Paying tribute to McNicholl School of Irish Dancing, Bernie said: “Sineacutead, Seamus and Niall have been really, really supportive of her. They also put in so much work behind the scenes and should be commended.” Bernie said following her success, Eimhear, who attends St Patricks College, Maghera, was welcomed home last week by her proud family and friends. “Eimhear just couldnt wait to get back to see everybody to celebrate her success. All the family were there with a big banner to welcome her home. Fr OReilly even congratulated her from the altar at the weekend masses.” Speaking about her success, Eimhear, who also plays camogie for Banagher GAC, said she really enjoyed the experience. “It is indescribable how Im feeling and I just want to thank Sinead, Seamus and Niall so much,” said the teenager. “I enjoyed dancing on that stage so much and I just couldnt wait to get on there because I didnt have a single nerve in my body. When my number was called out I just burst out into tears, I was just so happy. “My friends couldnt believe it. They were texting me and messaging me when I was crowned World Champion as they were watching it live on Facebook. “Im now planning to compete at the Worlds in April  so Ill be back at the dancing again this week,” she added. Teacher Sineacutead Burke also paid tribute to the north Derry dancer. She said: “Eimhear is a really good example of hard work pays off and not giving up. She deserves this title so much as she was simply outstanding . Her self belief and the hard work she put in are what earned her that success.”             ADVERTISEMENT --createDefaultAd --googletag.cmd.push Advertise with Us After ad loads, allow it to receive Those customers with a keypadmeter costs will increase by around pound per year. Raymond Gormley, head of energy at the Consumer Council, said: “This is only Power NI’s second increase in two years but the news will adversely impact those customers already experiencing financial pressures on their household budget, especially as the increase comes at the beginning of the New Year. “The Consumer Council would encourage Power NI customers on a standard tarf to think about switching payment option or changing billing method. Consumers could save around pound per year by benefiting from discounts offered by the supplier. “Consumers who are struggling financially with their energy bills or topping up their meter should
